subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml:
Find the rank of the matrix A =
\[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \\ 7 & 8 & 9 \end{bmatrix} \] and show that it is equal to the rank of its transpose.",
hints: Think about the relationship between row operations and matrix transformations.
Consider using Gaussian elimination to find the row echelon form of A.
The rank of a matrix is the maximum number of linearly independent rows (or columns).
solutionHtml:
Step 1: Use Gaussian elimination to transform A into its row echelon form.

\[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 1.5 \\ 0 & 0 & 4.5 \end{bmatrix} \]

Step 2: Count the number of linearly independent rows.

\[ \text{Rank}(A) = 2, since the first two rows are linearly independent. \]

",

subject: linear_algebra
title: Matrix Rank: Row and Column Rank
statementHtml: Find the rank of the matrix \[ A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \\ 5 & 6 \end{bmatrix}\].",
hints: Check if any row or column is a multiple of another.
Try to find the maximum number of linearly independent rows (or columns).
Use the fact that rank(A) = rank(AT)
solutionHtml:
To find the rank, we can use the fact that \[ \text{rank}(A) = \text{rank}(\mathbf{a}_1, \ldots, \mathbf{a}_n)\] where \[\mathbf{a}_i\] are the rows of A. In this case, we can see that the first two rows are linearly dependent, but the third row is not a multiple of any of the previous ones. Therefore, the rank is 2.

",

Find the rank of the matrix
\[A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \\ 5 & 6 \end{bmatrix}\] and determine if it has a unique solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions.",
hints: Check the row echelon form of A
Look for linearly independent rows in A
Consider the number of pivot elements in A
solutionHtml:
To find the rank of A, we can perform Gaussian elimination:


\[A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \\ 5 & 6 \end{bmatrix}\] becomes
\[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\]


The rank of A is the number of pivot elements, which is 1.
